2020 Risk Management Plan - City of Morganton. 



1. Executive Summary

The Catawba River Pollution Control Facility (CRPCF) is one of the many facilities owned and 

operated by the City of Morganton.  The Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) has an established Risk 

Management Plan (RMP) in accordance with the EPA and OSHA regulatory requirements.  The WWTP 

continues the use of a chlorine gas process at this site and is required to file an updated RMP and 

resubmit their plan.  A brief overview of the RMP and the associated policies at the plant are described 

below. 



2. Facility Description and Regulated Substances  

The Pollution Control Facility treats the City of Morganton's wastewater prior to discharge into 

the Catawba river.  The facility uses chlorine gas that is mixed with potable water and injected into 

wastewater stream to disinfect. Chlorine residual is maintained at appropriate levels to insure 

compliance for Fecal Coliform.  

2.1. The regulated substance handled at the wastewater treatment plant is chlorine and is stored in 

1-ton containers. 

2.2. Monitoring gas feed rate and chlorine residual samples are tested six times daily located at end 

of the chlorine contact chamber. 

2.3. At any given time, there are five containers onsite. 

2.4. The plant uses 60 - 80 lbs. per day. 



3. Prevention and Response Policies  

The City and the WWTP take an active role in preventing accidental releases by ensuring that its 

employees are properly trained in the safe operation of processes and procedures, as well as the safe 

handling of treatment chemicals.  The WWTP has established and maintains procedures for emergency 

notification and response.  These are reviewed with employees on a periodic basis and revised to 

accommodate changes in staffing when they occur.  To increase employee safety and awareness, the 

WWTP Standard Operating Procedures include the following: 

3.1. Maintain up-to-date safety information and operating proce

dures. 

3.2. Perform regular preventative maintenance. 

3.3. Provide annual refresher training on safe handling of chemicals. 

3.4. Conduct monthly safety SCBA/respirator training. 

3.5. Conduct annual drills and SCBA fitment testing.  

The WWTP has Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) for the three release scenarios which are 

discussed briefly in section 4.0.  These SOPs include guidance for conducting monthly safety training and 

drills for employees.  A log of training and a record of observations are maintained by the Responsible 

Operator in Charge and the Safety Officer.  

During the 2020 review process the team discussed and reviewed the PHA "What if" scenarios.  

Consensus of the group chose to not regenerate the "What if" portion and will maintain it as part of this 

updated RMP



4. Prevention Steps for Chlorine  

The prevention program fulfills the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management 

(PSM) rule and the EPA RMP rule, and includes  

4.1. Formal and on-the-job training. 

4.2. Written operating procedures. 

4.3. A process equipment preventive maintenance program.  



5. Release Scenarios  

The WWTP personnel discussed and determined to focus on three (3) release scenarios.  

Through group meetings and review of current SOPs they created standalone SOPs for each of the 

scenarios.  The following are the selected scenarios:  

5.1. Small leak. 

5.1.1.  Training and SOP were developed based on a small leak defined as a failed valve, loose 

connection, or malfunction of existing equipment.  The quantity of the leak was derived 

from a loss of 52 lbs. or less of an amount of chlorine gas. 

5.2. Tank Rupture. 

5.2.1.  Training and SOP for a rupture was established using suppliers' tank specification and 

their definition of a rupture.  Furthermore... 

5.3. Fire during delivery/exchange . 

5.3.1.  Training and SOP based on this worst-case-scenario includes retrieval of personnel, 

notification of emergency services, and

extinguishing procedures. 



6. Emergency Response Program  

This facility has established and maintains an emergency response program that is coordinated 

with the Morganton Public Safety Department.  The goals of the program are to protect on-site 

employees from the hazardous effects of the releases and to minimize the effects of a release that 

would be potentially hazardous to the residents.  The program is routinely reviewed and updated to 

reflect personnel and regulatory changes.   

Local Emergency Operations procedures were reviewed. Points of contacts and level of 

involvement in the event of one of the above scenarios were determined.  To further reduce the risk to 

plant personnel, during normal operating hours, everyone will evacuate and ORC/BORC will liaison to 

the Emergency Response Team (ERT).  During  after-hours/weekends/holidays, an operator will be the 

liaison to ERT while the ORC/BORC are in route to facility.    

6.1. Hazard Assessment - Offsite Consequence analysis shall be coordinated via the Emergency 

Responders and the Regional Hazardous Response team from Asheville.  

6.2. Front Gate is primary evacuation route/ assembly location. 

6.3. Accountability will be performed at assembly point(s). 

6.4. Detailed list of personnel and their roles see SOPs. 

6.5. Signage / Routes / Alternate / Method (Employees plan to leave the immediate area and 

assemble at specified location(s). 

6.6. See attached Figures 1-3 for safe distances. 



7. Accident History  

There have been no reported accidents in the last five years.  There was a release of a small 

amount of chlorine gas due to a failed regulating valve.  On early morning hours of May 30

2018, approximately 30  pounds of the chlorine gas was slowly released due to a  failing  regulator valve.  The 

following procedure was followed: 

7.1. Employees and construction workers were directed where to go during evacuation drill. 

7.2. Cylinder valves were immediately closed.

7.3. Piedmont Chlorinators Repair service was called in. 

7.4. Leak was identified at the point where gas is introduced into potable water before being 

entering the waste stream caused by a faulty valve. 

7.5. All employees and visitors were accounted for and no health issues were identified. 

Note:  This event took place under previous management personnel which have since retired from 

government service. 



8. Planned Changes for Improved Safety  

Ideas for changes to improve safety are actively sought from employees.  Employee meetings 

that focus on safety issues are held regularly at the facility.  Employees trained to recognize hazards and 

present ideas to eliminate them or to minimize the potential consequences of those hazards.  

During the development of this RMP document, a process hazard analysis of the chlorine system 

was conducted with key employees to fulfill the prevention program requirements.  During these 

sessions, recommendations were made for the purpose of improving safety and preventing accidental 

chemical releases.  Each recommendation will be or has been considered for implementation.  Though 

not all recommendations may be implemented, the exercise provided all affected employees with a 

heightened awareness of safety issues related to the covered processes. 

8.1. There currently is no plan/SOP to recover an individual if they were to succumb to the effect of 

the gas or become a casualty due to an existing or emerging health problem. 

8.2. Training through the crawl, walk, run concept will continue.  The Plant leadership team plans to 

include all personnel onsite during training events.  First through a classroom discussion, a 

walkthrough for each group and collect full speed drills.  The local emergency operations team 

will be included as the training and drill progress.  

8.3. Documentation will be maintained in both hardcopies and a digital version of material and sign-in

sheets. 

8.4. Meetings will be

placed on a "training" calendar to enhance predictability and encourage full 

participation of onsite personnel, external influencers, and schedule resources for the events. 

8.5. Modified delivery schedule of chlorine cylinders to add safety by reducing to a three tank 

exchange versus four. 

8.6. Upgrade siren and add visual alarms. 

8.6.1.  Place visual alarm in Operator Office. 

8.7. Install  auto-dialer(s) from alarm location.



 

Training and SOP for Small Leak.

A small leak is defined as 52 lbs. or less.



Procedures during Normal Operations.

1.    Alarm Sounds indicating a leak.

1.1.    Operators attempt to assess the situation.

1.2.    ORC/BORC determines level of emergency response, Calls (911).

2.    IF it is determined the leak can be remedied safely and quickly.

2.1.    Operators don personal protective equipment and SCBA.

2.2.    Notify plant personnel triggering evacuation to predetermined safe distance.

2.3.    Begin accountability process.

3.    Operators return to chlorine building with PPE/SCBA to determine or verify leak location. 

3.1.    Immediately Shut-off both tank's feed valve with wrench regardless.

3.2.    Electronic, failed alarm, sensor, etc.

3.3.    Connection, hose, pipe, supply line, etc.

4.    IF it is determined the leak cannot be remedied safely:

4.1.    Operators evacuate facility to predetermined location and wait for emergency services.

5.    IF leak occurs during after-hours/weekends/holidays:

5.1.    Operators evacuate to predetermined location and call (911) informing of chlorine gas leak.

5.2.    After calling (911), Operators call ORC/BORC and notify then of the situation.

5.2.1.    ORC/BORC immediately respond, and meet at the evacuation point.

6.    Wait for Emergency Services to arrive.

6.1.    ORC/BORC becomes a Liaison to Manager of Public Safety.

6.2.    Verify Regional Hazardous Response team is in route.

6.3.    Public Safety to assess situation.

7.    File report with necessary agencies.



Procedures during the delivery and exchange of Chlorine

cylinders.  

1.    Leak is detected or identified.

1.1.    Operators attempt to assess the situation. 

1.2.    Operators / ORC / Truck Driver leave the area.

1.3.    ORC/BORC determines level of emergency response, Calls (911).

2.    IF it is determined the leak can be remedied safely and quickly.

2.1.    Operators don personal protective equipment and SCBA.

2.2.    Notify plant personnel triggering evacuation to predetermined safe distance.

2.3.    Begin accountability process.

3.    IF it is determined the leak cannot be remedied safely and quickly.

3.1.    Operators evacuates facility to predetermined location.  

4.    Wait for Emergency Services to arrive.

4.1.    ORC/BORC Liaison to Manager of Public Safety.

4.2.    Verify Regional Hazardous Response team is in route.

4.3.    Public Safety will assess the situation.

5.    File report with necessary agencies.



Training and SOP for a Tank Rupture.

Procedures if rupture occurs during the delivery and exchange of Chlorine cylinders.  

1.    Leak is detected or identified.

1.1.    Operators attempt to assess the situation. 

1.2.    Operators / ORC / Truck Driver leave the area.

1.3.    ORC/BORC determines level of emergency response, Calls (911).

2.    IF it is determined the leak can be remedied safely and quickly.

2.1.    Operators don personal protective equipment and SCBA.

2.2.    Returns to Chlorine Building to make repairs / shut-off valve when applicable.

2.3.    Notify plant personnel triggering evacuation to predetermined safe distance.

2.4.    Begin accountability process.

3.    Complete evacuation and accountability.

4.    Wait for Emergency Services to arrive.

4.1.    ORC/BORC Liaison to Manager of Public Safety.

4.2.    Verify Regional Hazardous Response team is in route.

4.3.    Public Safety will assess the situation.

5.    File report with necessary agencies.
